speaker: Clinician
text: Marcus, your aripiprazole shot is due Friday; the log shows only four buprenorphine–naloxone strips left. Any missed doses since switching?

speaker: Patient
text: Uh, I, I think I took them each morning, but yesterday I dropped the pack between the seats, so I'm not totally sure I swallowed one.

speaker: Clinician
text: Okay, no shame, it happens. Any sweats, yawning, or muscle cramps hinting at withdrawal after that maybe-missed dose?

speaker: Patient
text: I felt kinda restless last night, kept tapping the steering wheel, but, uh, no chills or goosebumps. I figured it was the cold air outside.

speaker: Patient
text: My arm from the last shot’s still a little sore, like a lump when I lean back. That normal, right?

speaker: Patient
text: Also I’m parking by the river now, and the thermometer on the dash says thirty-two at night. Does that mess much with the blister packs?

speaker: Patient
text: Sometimes the films taste extra bitter. Not always, just sometimes. Is that the naloxone, or maybe they went bad from the cold out there overnight?

speaker: Patient
text: And, uh, the pharmacy said I’m at my limit till next week. Do I just wait or get samples somewhere?

speaker: Patient
text: Case worker mentioned a lockbox, but no one’s called. Should I keep asking them yet?

speaker: Clinician
text: Yes—freeze under 15°F hurts the films, but thirty-two is okay. Keep them tucked inside your jacket pocket overnight.

speaker: Clinician
text: That knot at the shot site is normal; massage or warm compress will ease it.

speaker: Clinician
text: I’ll issue an emergency five-day card, and nudge the lockbox team this afternoon for you.
